official-title.#text:
To address the prevalence of sexual harassment and sexual
		  assault in the Armed Forces.

sponsor.#tail: introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

short-title.#text:
Track It to Prevent It
			 Act

text.#text:
This Act may be cited
			 as the
The table of contents for this Act is as follows:

toc-entry.#text: Sec. 1. Short title; table of contents.

Sec. 4. Improved climate assessments and dissemination and
				tracking of results.

Sec. 5. Inclusion of letter of reprimands, nonpunitive letter
				of reprimands and counseling statements.

Sec. 8. Review of security of military installations, including
				barracks and multi-family residences.

Sec. 9. Review of the Office of Diversity Management and Equal
				Opportunity role in sexual harassment cases.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
makes the following
			 findings:

,
			 3,374 sexual assault cases involving a member of the Armed Forces were reported
			 in fiscal year 2012, a 6 percent increase in the number of reported cases in
			 fiscal year 2011.

text.#text: According to the

However, approximately 26,000 members of
			 the Armed Forces made an anonymous report of a sexual assault in fiscal year
			 2012, a substantial increase from fiscal year 2011.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, of
			 the 6.1 percent of female members of the Armed Forces who experienced

term.#tail:
in fiscal year 2012, 77 percent also
			 experienced sexual harassment and, of the 1.2 percent of male members of the
			 Armed Forces who experienced

in fiscal
			 year 2012, 52 percent also experienced sexual harassment.

text.#text: According to the

Sixty-two percent
			 of those members who experienced unwanted sexual contact also perceived some
			 form of social, administrative, or professional retaliation.

Climate
			 assessments are required by law and commanders at all levels must comply as it
			 is their core responsibility to create a safe and healthy environment for the
			 unit.

Trends in bad
			 behavior and reoccurring actions that harm the members of the unit, such as
			 sexual harassment and sexual assault, must be identified earlier through
			 improved performance assessments and better reporting by commanders at all
			 levels.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
report, two of the primary reasons why members decide not
			 to report sexual harassment and sexual assault incidents are because they do
			 not think anything will be done about the incident if they report it and they
			 think that reporting the incident will adversely impact their military
			 career.

text.#text: According to a recent

As long as
			 commanders at any level continue to condone or ignore certain types of sexual
			 misconduct, this behavior will continue to be prevalent in the military
			 obstructing the change in culture.
In this Act

has the meaning given such term in Department of
			 Defense Directive 1350.2, Department of Defense Military Equal Opportunity
			 Program.

text.#text: The term

header.#text:
Improved climate
			 assessments and dissemination and tracking of results

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall ensure that
			 the results of command climate assessments are provided to the relevant
			 individual commander and to the next higher level of command.

text.#text: The

header.#text:
Improved
			 dissemination of results in chain of command

text.#text:
The Secretary of
			 each military department shall include in the performance evaluations and
			 assessments used by each Armed Force under the jurisdiction of the Secretary a
			 designated form where senior commanders can indicate whether the commander has
			 conducted the required climate assessments.

If a commander is found to not have
			 conducted the required climate assessments, the failure shall be noted in the
			 commander’s performance evaluation and be considered a serious factor during
			 consideration for any subsequent promotion.

header.#text:
Effect of
			 failure to conduct assessment

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall
			 develop a system to track whether commanders are conducting command climate
			 assessments.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Inspector General of the Department of Defense

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, unit commanders shall gather
			 all the climate assessments from the unit and develop a compliance report that,
			 at a minimum, shall include the following:
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Inspector General of the Department of Defense

text.#text: Working with the

A
			 comprehensive overview of the concerns members of the unit expressed in the
			 climate assessments.

Data showing how
			 leadership is perceived in the unit.

A
			 detailed strategic plan on how leadership plans to address the expressed
			 concerns.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall require commanders to include letter of reprimands, nonpunitive
			 letter of actions and counseling statements involving substantiated cases of
			 sexual harassment or sexual assault in the performance evaluation report of a
			 member of the Armed Forces for the purpose of—

text.#text: The

header.#text:
Inclusion of
			 letter of reprimands, nonpunitive letter of reprimands and counseling
			 statements

text.#text:
identifying and
			 preventing trends of bad behavior early and effectively disciplining repeated
			 actions which hinder units from fostering a healthy climate; and

preventing the
			 transfer of sexual offenders.

The
			 Secretary of each military department shall develop an assessment program
			 modeled after the current Department of the Army Multi-Source Assessment and
			 Feedback (MSAF) Program, known in this section as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall submit to

a
			 report containing the results of an assessment of the feasibility of including
			 the 360-degree approach as part of the performance evaluation reports.

text.#text:
Not later than 90 days after the date of
			 the enactment of this Act, the

header.#text:
Report on
			 inclusion in performance evaluation reports

text.#text:
The Secretary of
			 each military department shall include individual counseling as part of the
			 performance evaluation process.

The Secretary of
			 each military department shall conduct health welfare inspections on a monthly
			 basis in order to ensure and maintain security, military readiness, good order,
			 and discipline of all units of the Armed Forces under the jurisdiction of the
			 Secretary. Results of the Health Welfare Inspections shall be provided to both
			 the commander and senior commander.

header.#text:
Review of
			 security of military installations, including barracks and multi-family
			 residences

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall conduct a review
			 of security measures on United States military installations, specifically with
			 regard to barracks and multi-family residences on military installations, for
			 the purpose of ensuring the safety of members of the Armed Forces and their
			 dependents who reside on military installations.

evaluate the

			 security personnel at all points of entry into barracks and multi-family
			 residences on military installation.
